Award.AwardTitle: Some Inverse Problems for Obstacles and Drift-Diffusion and Elasticity Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is concerned with analysis and design of numerical algorithms for reconstructing solutions and coefficients of partial differential equations from remote data. One of central topics is the study of increasing stability of the continuation of (acoustical and electromagnetic) waves. Another central topic is about uniqueness, stability, and methods of reconstruction of obstacles from boundary or scattering measurements, with emphasis on practical situations (in particular, on use of several frequencies or time data). The proposed research on drift-diffusion equations is concentrated around evaluation of doping profile in semiconductors and protein region in ion channels, as well finding volatility of option markets. The PI plans to obtain Carleman estimates for hyperbolic systems of anisotropic (including transversely isotropic) elasticity. All these research areas are challenging and central in applied mathematics. He will continue working on outstanding analytical problems, like uniqueness in the three-dimensional inverse conductivity problem with local data. Energy (including Carleman) estimates, harmonic and micro local analysis and potential theory will be main tools of this research.

The research on increasing stability of continuation and of locating obstacles is crucial for enhancing resolution of remote sensing in a variety of civil and military applications. Finding the doped area of semiconductor devices is of value for quality control in computer industry, and monitoring of ion channels is of fundamental interest in biology and medicine. The study of nondestructive evaluation of elastic properties is quite important in aviation, car, and construction industries, geophysics, and medicine. The PI will train graduate students preparing them for challenges of science and industry. Goals of this project have important applications to engineering, geophysics, and medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the main goals of this project was study of stability (and hence resolution) of prospecting of obstacles or media by stationary (acoustic or electromagnetic waves).  It was found that for low frequency stability is very weak, resulting in possibility of finding only 5-7 parameters of the unknown object, while increasing frequency one can expect much more detailed recovery. Increasing stability was demonstrated (analytically and numerically) for continuation of the waves under and without convexity (nontrapping) assumptions and for the Schroedinger potential.  Stability issue is crucial for study and practical applications of inverse problems. It was and still is an object of intensive research. One of promising (and surprising for geometrical optics )  outcomes of this project is establishing of increasing stability without convexity assumptions. For applications it means that one can recover a distant object by (higher frequency acoustical or electromagnetic) prospecting by placing sensors on an arbitrary observation site, while convexity assumptions require that sensors surround this object.

It was shown that practically available data are sufficient to (uniquely) find simple (e.g. polygonal) shape of the so called doped area of a basic semiconductor device. A fast numerical algorithm for finding this shape was proposed and implemented. This contributes to quality control of industrial semiconductors production.

A rigorous analysis of the recovery of volatility of financial (option) markets was implemented. The fastest and reliable numerical algorithm for recovery of linearly time dependent volatility from realistic (European options) market data was proposed. The linear time dependence enables to predict volatility in near future from current data.

A new model of finding of the size and shape of floating (ocean) ice was proposed. It was shown that readility avalaible gradiometric data are sufficient for unique identification of this shape. A new effective numerical algorithm based on the level set method was proposed and tested in the two and three dimensional settings. Evaluation of size and shape of ice is a challenging problem which helps with evaluation of  global warming.

Contemporary science and engineering are in need  of detailed mathematical modeling (and subsequent computer simulation) . Systems of partial differential equations are much more precise models, than scalar equations. Identification and control questions for systems are far more challenging than for single equations and they are mostly open. One of most diffucult and important (for geophysics, material science, and medicine) is the (anisotropic dynamical) system of elasticity. One of outcomes of this proejct is a derivation of previously unknown so called Carleman estimates for some anisotropic   (transversely isotropic) systems. These estimates imply (exact) controllability and uniqueness and best possible stability of recovery of elastic properties from exterior measurements of elastic displacements. The proposed methodology (special upper principal triangularization) has a strong potential for handling more general important systems of  electromagnetism and elasticity.
